title: Which one of Agatha Christie book is best — And Then There Were None, The Murder of Roger Ackroyd, or Murder on the Orient Express? - Quora
tags: Murder on the Orient Express (1934 novel)
And Then There Were None (1939 book)

response.answer_text: I haven’t read Murder of Roger Ackroyd yet… * Highlight “‘yet’” * But when it comes down to , “MURDER ON ORIENT EXPRESS” or “AND THEN THERE WERE NONE”., I’d choose the latter. After all, it is ‘THE WORLD’S BEST SELLING MYSTERY’… However, “Murder on Orient express” is also pretty interesting too. A person who loves reading (like me)-specially mystery- would love these two books. For those who aren’t much into reading detective stories , would probably prefer to just skim through “murder on orient express”. But will never, I mean ever, prefer to skip any part of ‘And Then There Were None’. On a scale of 1–10., I’d give Murder On Orient Express ——— 9.5 And Then There Were None ——— 10+++ * I know, I know, 10 is the maximum…but sorry, it deserves a 10+* P.S. : If you haven’t read these two yet, I’d like to mention something. Don’t just strain your brain while reading them, your theory is most likely to go wrong. Then again, you can’t stop your brain. After all., that is the pleasure of reading a mystery novel. P.P.S.: I’m definitely diving into The Murder of Roger Ackroyd after submitting this answer. EDIT: Completed The Murder Of Roger Ackroyd… Well, First of all, It was Good… (Obviously…Duh!) On a scale of 1–10., To be honest… I couldn’t decide if it was an 8 or a 9… Ok… 8 it is… It usually goes this way- you start reading it…you formulate your own theories but ultimately Hercule Poirot proves them wrong and gives his own peculiar yet interesting solution… so, for a change, half way through the book, I thought, “Who is the most unlikely person to be proved guilty? ” I used my little grey cells and guess what, I stumbled upon a character but dismissed that thought and went on with my reading… Guess what happened? Yep…you’re right… I guessed it correctly even though I couldn’t -for the life of me- comprehend its possibility… However, Hercule Poirot vividly explained everything… And I’m HAPPY… Yay!!! “It is not easy to hide things from Hercule Poirot. He has knack of finding out” “The truth, however ugly in itself, is always curious and beautiful to the seeker after it” Increasing heart rate and sparkling eyes with anticipation of the moment of truth are common in the last 10-20% of every book.

Agatha Christie is a spin master (or mistress!). She had the admirable ability to take a formula (which I shall call her whodunit formula) and then add her own individual twist on that formula to create mysteries that were both surprising and refreshing. The 3 you have asked about are all in that special "twisted" formula category. You did not mention if you have read any of these 3 books. As such, I will not include any spoilers in this answer. Since it is a Christie novel, they all deal with murder. All of them deal with expression and suppression. What the individuals in the novels express and what they suppress are very often clues to their own character and also in the solution of the mystery. In addition, they are all "fair" stories like almost all of Agatha Christie's novels were - i.e. a person who reads the stories with attention can logically solve the mystery. She was fair to her readers that way. What is different about them? 2 of them are in the "locked room" variety of mystery stories, while one literally had a locked room in the story. The 3 of them played with the idea and identity of the murderer in very creative ways. The clue here would be me, all or none! The mood and language used in the stories reflected the time of Agatha's life. Roger Ackroyd (1926) was narrated, Orient Express (1934) was full of activity and movement and None (1940) was mysterious and dark. They are all 3 very fine specimens of a body of work (forgive the pun!) that is exceptional! Don't miss any of them!
